The Scheme is owned by the Construction Industry Council (CIC) and implemented by the Hong Kong Green Building Council (HKGBC).
:END_ID: It aims to help consumers, building professionals and policy makers identify environmentally preferable building materials and products.

:START_ID: The Standard sets out the assessment criteria and their benchmarks for glazing products.
:END_ID: It governs the application and award of a label under the Scheme.

:START_ID: The Standard defines the verification methods to determine which labelling grade should be awarded to the product.
:END_ID: It aims to help consumers, building professionals and policy makers identify environmentally preferable building materials and products.

:START_ID: The Standard neither modifies nor supersedes laws and regulations.
:END_ID: Compliance with this Standard is not a substitute for, and does not assure, compliance with any applicable laws or regulations.

:START_ID: Compliance with this Standard is not a substitute for, and does not assure, compliance with any applicable laws or regulations.
:END_ID: Compliance with all applicable laws and regulations is a prerequisite for the manufacturing and marketing of the product.

:START_ID: The glazing area of a building could account for 10 to 25% of a building's exposed surface.
:END_ID: The greatest environmental impact of glazing products is resulted from the energy losses during the building operation stage.

:START_ID: The purposes of the assessment criteria developed for glazing are, therefore, to promote the use of energy-efficient building envelop, and to minimise the environmental impact.
:END_ID: Many of the glazing products contain substances that may be harmful to the environment and human health.

:START_ID: The scope of this Standard is applicable to glass in fixed and opening windows, window doors, and other elements of building envelop.
:END_ID: Glass blocks and bricks or glass used for internal partitions are excluded from this Standard.

Glazing products are commonly used for fixed and opening windows, window doors, curtain walls and other elements of the building envelop
The glazing area of a building could account for 10 to 25% of a building's exposed surface
The glazing area of a building serves as an interface to transmit light and provide outdoor view
Common types of glazing being used in architectural applications include clear and tinted float glass, tempered glass, and laminated glass as well as a variety of coated glasses, etc
Common types of glazing being used in architectural applications include clear and tinted float glass, tempered glass, and laminated glass as well as a variety of coated glasses, etc
Common types of glazing being used in architectural applications include clear and tinted float glass, tempered glass, and laminated glass as well as a variety of coated glasses, etc
Common types of glazing being used in architectural applications include clear and tinted float glass, tempered glass, and laminated glass as well as a variety of coated glasses, etc
Many of the glazing products contain substances that may be harmful to the environment and human health
The greatest environmental impact of glazing products is resulted from the energy losses during the building operation stage due to their long technical service life

The purposes of the assessment criteria developed for glazing are to promote the use of energy-efficient building envelop, and to minimise the environmental impact through stringent assessment criteria on the production process and use of materials

The purposes of the assessment criteria developed for glazing are to promote the use of energy-efficient building envelop, and to minimise the environmental impact through stringent assessment criteria on the production process and use of materials
The scope of this Standard is applicable to glass in fixed and opening windows, window doors, and other elements of building envelop
